abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is unsatisfactory,
            with ratings such as unlikely sustainability, negligible
            institutional development impacts, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank, and Borrower. Several lessons
            are drawn from the project. The lack of control mechanisms,
            and weak management within the Education Fund to address
            insufficient budgetary resources to pay teacher salaries
            created problems, because as part of an emergency response,
            the overall environment was of weak capacity, and
            instability. Instead, building on the existing capacity, or
            outsourcing the fund's financial management would have
            been preferable, particularly the former option in terms of
            sustainability. Furthermore, the whole project concept was
            premised on the financial support of parents, and
            communities - in a continuing economic crisis with falling
            family revenues - including on an expectation that
            consumption taxes could be levied at the grassroots, which
            proved unrealistic, and almost jeopardized community
            voluntary contributions of public school fees. Rather, a
            careful assessment, and monitoring could have appropriately
            focused on beneficiary expectations. Despite a seemingly
            adequate implementation support by the Bank, and Borrower,
            failure to gauge the emergency situation, and weak
            governance hindered success, experienced by failed control
            mechanisms, preventable had public finance management been
            strengthened; because of mistaken assumptions that textbooks
            publishers would easily negotiate legitimate copyrights
            instead of easing procurement of generic textbooks; because
            of failure to adequately evaluate contractors capacity,
            explore procurement management, and provide needed technical
            support; and because of the absence of an agreed policy
            framework regarding decentralization to the regional level.

18154552.subsc: Sub-natl govt admin,Tertiary education,Primary education,Central government administration
18154552.theme: Education for all,Social analysis and monitoring,Gender,Decentralization,Administrative and civil service reform

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Rehabilitation Project is
            designed to reverse the rapid deterioration in the education
            sector in Togo following several years of social and
            political unrest and a decade of declining enrollment and
            quality. The project has two objectives: to improve the
            quality of schools and to develop better education system
            management. The project comprises two components: 1) the
            development of better schools through school construction
            and rehabilitation, provision of textbooks, and the Quality
            of Schools Initiative; and 2) development of better
            education system management through decentralized
            recruitment and financing of teachers, development of system
            managment tools including information and communication
            systems, budgetary programming and monitoring, consolidation
            of the minsterial restructuring by strengthening
            decision-making process and further decentralizing the
            responsibility for instructional as well as financial management.
